results.title: An Interview with Glenn James
results.brief_description: When Glenn James’ fellow soldiers returned from service in Vietnam, they told him they finally understood what it was like to be Indigenous - you get treated like rubbish. Vietnam soldiers were brought home under the cover of night and at best ignored. For James, this was nothing new. As he talks about the plight of others that he has committed his life to helping, James provides some insight into an indomitable spirit, and how he has focused his energy into creating positive change for others.

results.title: An Interview with George Derham
results.creator_credit: George Derham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: George Derham was called up to serve for Australia on the 4/4/44. He joined the Australian Navy and recalls his time there, of fitting in and standing out. Collecting Australian prisoners of war in Japan, two images affected Derham greatly - that of Tokyo after the extensive firebombing by the US, and the emaciated state of the prisoners of war. Despite this, Derham sees military life as a valuable part of his development and works hard to assist returned soldiers and their families.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Derham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: An Interview with Frank Cox
results.brief_description: Frank Cox signed up to joined the army to see what they had in store for him. He started work as a dispatch rider in Palestine and finished up in the Suez Canal as part of his training. After serving in Tobruk and Greece, Cox became a prisoner of war and has borne witness to the suffering of his colleagues.

results.title: An Interview with Colin Bannister
results.brief_description: In 1950, Colin Bannister sailed from Syndey to Singapore to defend the Malayan Government against an uprising in what was called ‘The Malayan Emergency’. Bannister’s time in Malaya has taught him about power and the important things in life.

results.title: An Interview with Alan Clark
results.brief_description: On the 16th May, 1941, Alan Clark was called up to serve for Australia in World War II. He tells of his time training in New South Wales, his decision to join the Air Force and the precise skill involved with dropping mines.

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2009]
results.brief_description: 10 interviews with Victorian war veterans, created as part of the “In our words : Stories from Victorian veterans” Digital Storytelling workshop in August 2009, with the support of the Department of Planning and Community Development, the Shrine of Remembrance, and the Victorian Veterans Council.

results.title: An Interview with Stan Guilfoyle
results.brief_description: When he was 13, Stan Guilfoyle was in an accident in which he nearly died. From then on he believed in seizing every moment. This enthusiasm for life took him to the Royal Australian Air Force, where he became proficient at flying, using only the instruments in his cockpit to navigate. He tells of his time in Indonesia during World War II and passionately shares his views on war.

results.title: An Interview with Shirley Cornish
results.brief_description: Shirley Cornish joined the army when a friend, from the store where she worked, said she would. She joined the Australian Womens Army Service and spent most of her life in the service of the army, and tells of her times there and friends made. Army life often bled into Shirley’s personal life, losing a rank in order to spend more time with her mother and, later, joining the Bentleigh War Widows and Widowed Mothers after her husband died. Shirley considers joining this association to be the best thing she ever did and even went on to become its president.

results.title: An Interview with Raymond Jungwirth
results.brief_description: Raymond Jungwirth wanted to fly a spitfire but was convinced to undergo observer training. Initially trained in Canada, Raymond was posted to Europe, where he spent most of World War II. Here he provides a heartfelt account of friends made and lost, the waste of human life and visiting Belsen after the war and the lasting impression that stayed with him even after he returned to Australia.

results.title: An Interview with Major General Jim Hughes
results.brief_description: Major General Jim Hughes joined the army just after World War II. Army life suited him and he served as a platoon commander in Korea in the 1950s. He details one particularly long Sunday, during this time, when his company was ambushed by the Chinese and resulted in him maturing considerably in one day.
